title: Determined Blind Source Separation with Sinkhorn Divergence-based Optimal Allocation of the Source Power
author: Jianyu Wang (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Shanzheng Guan (Northwestern Polytechnical University), Nicolas Dobigeon (University of Toulouse), Jingdong Chen (Northwestern Polytechnical University), ..., Senior Member, IEEE, Fellow, IEEE
relevance_why: The proposed enhancements to Blind Source Separation (BSS) via Sinkhorn divergence could be relevant for optimizing audio source separation tasks, which is a key area of interest in Dr. Liu's research.
background: The task focuses on recovering distinct sound sources from their mixtures captured by multiple microphones, particularly in challenging reverberant environments.
contribution: This paper introduces a method for improving established BSS algorithms via Sinkhorn divergence to more effectively align estimated and actual source distributions, leading to better separation performance.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Conventional methods like Independent Vector Analysis (IVA) and Independent Low-Rank Matrix Analysis (ILRMA) generally do not address model mismatches or inter-band dependencies effectively.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work incorporates Sinkhorn divergence to reallocate source power more optimally while addressing discrepancies in source models, which enhances the accuracy of source extraction.

key_innovation: Utilizes an optimal transport framework to adjust the estimated source distributions based on inter-band dependencies, providing a more accurate power allocation method.
real_world_impact: By improving audio source separation, this work has the potential to enhance technologies in telecommunications, hearing aids, and any system relying on clear audio input under noise conditions.
limitations: No limitations were explicitly mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.Sinkhorn divergence: **Sinkhorn divergence** is a regularized version of the Wasserstein distance used in optimal transport theory, allowing for computationally efficient alignment of probability distributions with added entropy regularization.
